**INSTITUTION PALLIATIVE CARE CONSULTATION
PATIENT NAME: **NAME[AAA, BBB M] ACCOUNT #: **ID-NUM **ROOM ATTENDING PHYSICIAN: **NAME[UUU] **NAME[VVV] CONSULTING PHYSICIAN: **NAME[UUU] **NAME[VVV] DATE OF ADMISSION: **DATE[Aug 25 2006] DATE OF CONSULTATION: **DATE[Aug 25 06]
REASON FOR CONSULT:
1. Discussion of goals. 2. Symptoms.
Ms. **NAME[AAA] is a **AGE[in 70s]-year-old woman who was admitted to **INSTITUTION on **DATE[Aug 25] for some change in mental status, confusion, and agitation. She had recently been put on _____. A condition C was called because the patient was found down in a pool of vomit. A CT of the head showed an acute right frontoparietal parenchymal bleed with intravascular extension and mild right to left subuncal herniation.
The patient was brought to the unit, sedated with propofol, and put on the ventilator. Her initial blood pressure Was 210. Since she has been in the unit, she has remained comfortable.
I talked to the patient's husband, sister, son, granddaughter, and niece for a total of 70 minutes. Greater than 60% of that was face-to-face time with the patient and family.
The patient has a history of hypertension.
Social history: She lives with her husband and has the family as stated above. No alcohol, drugs, or tobacco.
Family history: Unremarkable.
Review of systems: Review of systems at the current time is unobtainable from the patient; however, the family thinks the patient is comfortable.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1. Coronary artery disease/CABG. 2. CNS aneurysm. 3. Dementia.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:
The patient is sedate, not responsive to my voice. She is stable on the ventilator.
Vital signs: Stable and in no acute distress.
Chest: Clear breath sounds anteriorly.
Abdomen: Nontender.
Extremities: No edema.
LABORATORY TESTS:
CT as per above. Chest x-ray shows some mild pulmonary edema. CT of the head from **DATE[Aug 18] shows there are some chronic changes and old cerebellar hemorrhages. BUN and creatinine 11 and 0.8. Calcium 7.6, albumin in **DATE[Apr] was 4.3. LFTs in **DATE[Apr] were within normal limits. Hematocrit is 42.
ASSESSMENT: The patient is a **AGE[in 70s]-year-old woman who suffered a major stroke.
PLAN:
1. At the current time, the patient remains comfortable. I have no further symptom recs. 2. If shortness of breath becomes an issue, I would use opiates, for example, morphine 2 mg q. 2 hours p.r.n. 3. If delirious, would use Haldol 1 to 2 mg IV q. 1 hours p.r.n..
GOALS: The major amount of time was spent talking to the family about goals. I did discuss with them how this is an acute infarct, and we are not entirely sure how this will play out. However, given that this was a large infarct with herniation, it is very serious. I tried to stress to them that regardless of what happens, we would keep their loved one comfortable and to the best we can to maximize her care. I did, however, try to prepare them to the fact that this was a severe stroke that the patient may not recover from. The family certainly seemed to understand. They are waiting to hear from neurosurgery to hear if there are any other options or to hear what their opinion is. At the current time, they stressed no needs, but they were going to talk together as a family.
